document.docAuthor: Volynkin, Anton V., Dubatolov, Vladimir V. & Kishida, Yasunori
document.masterDocTitle: Barsura Volynkin, Dubatolov & Kishida, gen. nov., with descriptions of three new species (Lepidoptera, Erebidae, Arctiinae)

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Barsura Volynkin, Dubatolov & Kishida, gen. nov., with descriptions of three new species (Lepidoptera, Erebidae, Arctiinae)

subSubSection.paragraph:
Barsine nubifascia Walker, [1865]
1964, List of the specimens of lepidopterous insects in the collection of the British Museum 31 : 251. ( Type locality: “Darjeeling”).

=
Barsine punctifascia Walker, 1869
, Characters of undescribed
Lepidoptera Heterocera 1869 : 9
( Type locality: not stated), syn. rev.

Type material examined. Syntype of
Barsine nubifascia
( Fig. 5 ): male, handwritten greyish label "
Barsine nubifascia
" / handwritten greyish label "Sikkim, W.S. Atkinson 72-12" / round greyish label with a green ring "Type" / white printed label with QR-code "NHMUK010604288" (Coll. NHM); holotype of
Barsine punctifascia
( Fig. 6 ): ♀, handwritten greyish label "Type
Barsine punctifascia
" / printed greyish label "Coll. Moore 91-127" / round greyish label with a green ring "Type" / white printed label with QR-code "NHMUK010604292" (Coll. NHM).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 1–4.
Barsura nubifascia
morphology. 1, male genital capsule; 2, male aedeagus with everted vesica; 3, female genitalia; 4, venation scheme (after Hampson 1900).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. Forewing length is 13–14.5 mm in ♂ and 16–17 mm in ♀ . Externally, the species ( Figs. 5–8 ) differs from other members of the
B. nubifascia
species-group ( Figs. 9–16 ) by its less contrast and diffuse forewing pattern and intensive ochreous-yellow hindwings. The male genitalia ( Fig. 34 ) are close to those of
B. clandestina
( Fig. 35 ), but differ by the unilobe distal costal process, the much narrower ventral costal process, the narrower and longer distal saccular process, presence of numerous thorns on aedeagus carinal plate, a larger number of cornuti in the subbasal ventral diverticulum, the much larger lateral cornuti, and absence of a long distal cornutus. The female genitalia ( Fig. 48 ) differ clearly from those of all other congeners ( Figs 49–54 ) by the long and relatively narrow ductus bursae and the very large lateral sclerotized lobes of corpus bursae.
Distribution. The species is widespread in the Himalayan Region: Pakistan ( Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Kashmir), Nepal , NW, N and E India ( Punjab , Himachal Pradesh , north of West Bengal , Sikkim ).
